posts.cooked: Using pathplanner, my auto just always goes sideways, no matter what path i map. It seems to be trying to move in a large circle. My code is here: GitHub - Mateo-Johnson/RobustSturdy3

posts.name: Scarlett Saam
posts.cooked: Setting the starting position in pathplanner might fix it; you also might have the auton set to the wrong side (for instance, if you’re setting up your robot on the blue side and your auton is set up for the red side, it would shoot over to the blue side if your starting position isn’t correct. Also make sure you’re implementing the right auton path into your code. It’s possible that the name of the auton that your code is receiving doesn’t match the name of the auton you’re intending to implement. Are you using an autochooser or just typing the pathplanner auton name into your code?
I’m using a sendablechooser for autos. I think the paths are one the right side too.

posts.name: Scarlett Saam
posts.cooked:
Are you setting a starting position for the auton?

Example below of starting position
I don’t think so, I turned it off to see if that would solve the issue. The issue persisted when the starting position was set

posts.name: Scarlett Saam
posts.cooked: I would add a starting position to make sure that it’s not an issue with pre-existing coordinates (Though that might not be the issue) Are your drivebase motors assembled and wired correctly? My team had issues when one of our swerve motors was missing some sort of part in it. Does teleop control work? If neither auton or teleop work, it’s probably not pathplanner that’s the issue. You also might need to invert some of the controls for your drivebase so that all the wheels turn the intended direction. Maybe also check to make sure the motor IDs are all correct too. Check your battery as well, every now and then our robot starts acting goofy and then it’s just the battery. Probably not the issue since your problem sounds like it’s unrelated to power but it’s good to check.

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
Make sure you’re not manually setting the gyro yaw (or the pose) in addition to the pathplanner starting position. If you set both they can fight each other. I’ve found that letting pathplanner use it’s own preset starting pose is nearly 100% reliable, so long as you don’t also set it manually. So for example, if you set the pose to 60 degrees and also have the pathplanner set to 60 degrees. It will drive at a 60 degree angle (straight into the wall) when you intend for it to go forward.

For the second issue (moving in a large circle) check that the distances and speeds you are feeding into your getVelocity and getPosition values in your swerve modules are in meters and are accurate for your drive and gear ratio. If you are telling planner that you moved 12 meters and you actually moved 12 inches it’s not going to go very far (ask me how I know).

(Okay…  we had a similar situation where it drew a tiny version of our auto in a little circle because it was moving inches instead of meters. It was an adorable little auto, but not very useful. )
